body: tracked at https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/939

This looks pretty good so far - one thing we could think about is how we can implement squirrel event hooks and help people to create shortcuts (i.e. all the jazz that happens in https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/browser/squirrel-update.coffee#L230). Having a default handler that just creates a shortcut to our own app would be p.cool
@paulcbetts yeah i will come up with a default handler for the squirrel events. something that is extensible

@paulcbetts i have cleaned up the current pull request. still missing: squirrel events default handler.

Are you looking for something like this? 

main.coffee

``` Coffeescript
app           = require('app')
BrowserWindow = require('browser-window')
crashReporter = require('crash-reporter')
autoUpdate    = require('auto-update')
mainWindow    = null


crashReporter.start()

return if autoUpdater.squirrelEventsDefaultHandler?()

autoUpdater.setFeedUrl('http://mycompany.com/myapp/latest');

... etc
```

the downside is that this default handler has to be called explicitly. i could of course run it by default in the  `auto-updater.coffee` but then the user has no way of disabling it.

Any news on this? I'm currently reading through the atom/electron source to try understanding how to do all of the update logic properly. If this is going to become the state of the art soon, would be good to know :)
@patrickdet I'll have a look at this soon, sorry for spacing on it

As far as I can see, when you run `Update.exe --download` it will check `RELEASES` and if an update is available will download the `.nupkg` file and finally emit `update-available`.

Then you run `Update.exe --update` that will download again the `.nupkg` file (according to my tests), will run the new application version with `--squirrel-install` and finally emit `update-downloaded`.

I can see two not-optimal behaviours, but I'm not sure yet if we can fix it:
1. The `.nupkg` file (usually a large file) will be downloaded 2 times
2. `update-downloaded` is emitted once the update has been downloaded **and applied**

`Update.exe --install` is an internal command, you definitely want `update.exe --update` to finally apply the update. `update.exe --download` might suck and be broken, we need to fix it up. 

> The .nupkg file (usually a large file) will be downloaded 2 times

This is weird, we should just fix that.

@jessep, @paulcbetts is right. `Update.exe --install` is an internal command and can't be called to install an update after you call `Update.exe --download`. I spent some time doing experiments and I still didn't find a solution to avoid the double download (except patching Squirrel for Windows, that was out of my scope). Any help from @paulcbetts here is very appreciated.

> The docs seem to imply that it would just return metadata, but it isn't totally clear. 

So the problem is, that in order to return the release notes, we have to actually download the file - this is an unfortunate aspect to Squirrel's design, but it makes `RELEASES` super small and super easy to parse / edit. Tradeoffs!

@paulcbetts Is downloading `RELEASES` from the upcoming `auto-updater` module version for Windows, a viable solution or not? The workflow would be: manually check `RELEASES`, then `Update.exe --update`.
Any update on this?
@paulcbetts It sound like you think the current pull request is adequate? Any reason not to merge this pull request in that case?

@paulcbetts nevermind, i just saw that there's the outstanding question about [squirrel events default handler](https://github.com/atom/electron/pull/1984#issuecomment-114137509) anyway, i'm eager to use this :/
@paulcbetts, could you answer the [squirrel events default handler](https://github.com/atom/electron/pull/1984#issuecomment-114137509) question, so we can move forward with this?
Whenever the question is answered I will gladly update my PR. I also want the auto-updater for my own projects ;)

@patrickdet, in regards to [squirrel events default handler](https://github.com/atom/electron/pull/1984#issuecomment-114137509), I think it's fine to call the handler explicitly and pass to it what ever it needs. That's pretty much the way it's implemented in [atom](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/browser/main.coffee#L51-L55) (on start it calls `handleStartupEventWithSquirrel` which sets up everything).

I think we should go a head and finish it. If we are not sure about the quality of the API, we can mark it as "experimental" (AKA it might break in future versions) in the docs and let people start playing with it so we can get real feedback.
Sorry for totally spacing on this, lemme read through a few things today
